node.text:
“You take away the distraction of language and view the spreads as just abstract shapes.” 

Product designer and software developer Eric Li (@eli8527) talks about the beauty of poetry without the distraction of language in #MarcelBroodthaers’s “Un Coup de dés jamais n’abolira le hasard (A throw of the dice will never abolish chance).” 

The work is a homage to the 1887 modernist poem by French poet Stéphane Mallarmé, who used language to push conventions of space and typography—stretching sentences across spreads and using multiple typefaces to abstract both form and content. Broodthaers wrote: "Mallarmé is at the source of modern art...He unwittingly invented modern space."

In designing his edition, Broodthaers blocked out the lines of the original work with solid black bars of varying width, dependent on the original type size, turning the original text into an abstract image of the poem.

Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience Broodthaers’s work in “Artist’s Choice: Yto Barrada—A Raft” (@ytobarrada).

@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.

node.text:
“It’s a contemplative painting for me, something that you can get lost in. This painting provides an opportunity to quiet my own mind.”

Cara Manes, Associate Curator in the Department of Painting and Sculpture, finds a haven from the chaos of the everyday in Vasudeo S. Gaitonde’s “Painting, 4.”
 
Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience "Painting, 4" in Gallery 404: Planes of Color.

node.text:
...so bright you want to keep your shades on! MoMA security officer Sheldon A. Clarke (@sheldonaclarke) describes what it’s like to see Vincent van Gogh’s luminous painting “The Starry Night” in person and tells us about Van Gogh’s dedication to his work even during one of the most difficult points in his life, a reminder never to give up on artistic vision.

“This encouraged me and a lot of other artists that it doesn’t really matter where you are in life. It’s so important to just keep pursuing your goal, keep pursuing your vision, and do it all the way to the end.”

Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience Van Gogh’s work in our fifth-floor galleries.

@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.

node.text:
In “Nation,” photographer Deana Lawson wanted to capture the “majesty of black life, a nuanced black life, one that is by far more complex, deep, beautiful, celebratory, tragic, weird, strange.” Here, guest specialist Djata Doumbouya (@adoseofdjata) takes a close look at Lawson’s photograph and finds a connection to the people and the space within the frame.
 
Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience "Nation" in Gallery 215: History is the Present Tense.
 
@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.
#DeanaLawson

node.title: “This picture makes me happy...like there is something here for all of us.”

node.text:
“We’re sitting here in the audience looking up at this elaborately decorated production of their lives.”

Kristen Di Lonardo, department manager in Visitor Engagement, looks behind the curtain at Florine Stettheimer’s “Family Portrait, II” and marvels at its intricate detail and sense of theatricality. Stettheimer was a painter, poet, playwright, designer...and a celebrated salon host who threw eccentrically decorated parties that brought together luminaries from the worlds of art, dance, literature, music, and theater. These figures, along with the artist and her family, often appear in her elaborately detailed portraits.

Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience Stettheimer’s work in our fifth-floor galleries.

@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.

node.title: The cool, witty, empowered aura of feminists in Florine Stettheimer’s world

node.text:
“At first maybe it looks decorative, but actually spending more time with this work... there's sort of an unsettling power about it."

Heidi Hirschl Orley, assistant director of Curatorial Affairs, talks about the conservation effort that brought new life to Séraphine Louis’s 1928 painting "Tree of Paradise." The long-overdue restoration of this work, which had never been cleaned, included removing soot from the candlelight Louis used while painting it.

Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience Louis’s work in our fifth-floor galleries.

@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.

node.title: The conservation effort behind Séraphine Louis’s 1928 “Tree of Paradise."

node.text:
“It's about the ways that we move through and inhabit space. It's about the stories that we can tell and the ways that we can find a sense of belonging."

Arlette Hernandez, Volkswagen Fellow for Digital Learning, takes a close look at two photographs from Alvin Baltrop’s series The Piers, which have preserved long-disappeared spaces where marginalized communities could enjoy a sense of belonging.

Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience Baltrop’s work in our second-floor galleries.

@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.

node.title: “He reminds us that, at the end of the day, architecture is about people.”

node.text: There’s just a few weeks left to be part of Amanda Williams's (@awstudioart) "Embodied Sensations," an installation that explores who has the freedom to move, and why, and the transformation of both public and virtual space during the pandemic. Participate from anywhere by taking an online survey from which movements will be generated, or sign up to be a performer at the Museum. More info at mo.ma/amandawilliams, or the link in our bio.

node.title: Ready to connect with other people again?

node.text:
"There are all these influences, from African art, Asian art, from Eastern Europe... that somehow create a harmony in the sculpture."

Veronika Molnar (@veronikaamolnar) an intern in the Department of Media and Performance, discusses the calming effect—and global influences—of Constantin Brancusi’s 1913 sculpture "Mlle Pogany."

Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience "Mlle Pogany" in our fifth-floor galleries.

@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.

node.title: The calming effect—and global influences—of Brancusi’s "Mlle Pogany"

node.text:
See through Paul Cézanne's eyes, and discover how drawing shaped the artist’s transformative vision. The exhibition brings together over 250 rarely seen works in pencil and watercolor, along with key paintings.

Don’t miss this once-in-a-generation experience. Become a member for priority access and see “Cézanne Drawing” first. Member Previews June 3-5. Exhibition opens June 6. Learn more at the link in our bio.

node.title: Member previews for "Cézanne Drawing" begin tomorrow!

node.text:
Today marks one year since George Floyd’s murder, a tragic anniversary in our country and around the world.

We invite you to join us in remembering George Floyd, and acknowledging the pain and horrific loss experienced by so many families and communities due to intolerable racism, violence, and injustice directed at Black Americans.

Today we will open our doors to the public at 10:45 a.m. EST., after MoMA staff observe 9 minutes and 29 seconds of silence to honor George Floyd's life, and reflect on the actions we must continue to take to fight systemic racism and injustice.

Visit the link in our bio to learn about some of the ways we can all fight racism and support justice and equality, and share your resources in the comments below to help us add to our ongoing list.

node.title: A moment of silence for George Floyd

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by MoMA The Museum of Modern Art on August 07, 2021 tagging @ellen.isaacs.

node.text:
Look familiar? This quilt is inspired by the window into our gallery stairwell from the Atrium!

Textile artist Ellen Isaacs recently emailed us saying the image of the stairwell stayed with her after a visit to MoMA a few years ago, so she spent time during lockdown recreating it in macrame for this quilt. Thank you @ellen.isaacs for sharing!

node.text:
“You take away the distraction of language and view the spreads as just abstract shapes.” 

Product designer and software developer Eric Li (@eli8527) talks about the beauty of poetry without the distraction of language in #MarcelBroodthaers’s “Un Coup de dés jamais n’abolira le hasard (A throw of the dice will never abolish chance).” 

The work is a homage to the 1887 modernist poem by French poet Stéphane Mallarmé, who used language to push conventions of space and typography—stretching sentences across spreads and using multiple typefaces to abstract both form and content. Broodthaers wrote: "Mallarmé is at the source of modern art...He unwittingly invented modern space."

In designing his edition, Broodthaers blocked out the lines of the original work with solid black bars of varying width, dependent on the original type size, turning the original text into an abstract image of the poem.

Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience Broodthaers’s work in “Artist’s Choice: Yto Barrada—A Raft” (@ytobarrada).

@uniqlousa is MoMA’s proud partner of #ArtForAll.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by MoMA The Museum of Modern Art on August 05, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
🍉 Summer picnic!

Paul Cézanne carefully arranged still life compositions in his studio, returning often to wine bottles and pitchers and apples, pears, and melons, all close at hand. In this still life, veils of watercolor transform an arrangement of solid objects into a kaleidoscopic scene while unpainted paper creates a luminous openness. This strategy of purposely leaving paper without pigment—sometimes called "unfinish"—is essential to #Cézanne's approach.  

See “Cézanne Drawing” at MoMA through September 25. Visit mo.ma/cezanne to book tickets (link in bio).

[Paul Cézanne. “Still Life with Cut Watermelon (Nature morte avec pastèque entamée). c. 1900.” Pencil and watercolor on paper, 12 3/8 × 19 1/8″ (31.5 × 48.5 cm). Fondation Beyeler, Riehen/Basel. Beyeler Collection. Photo: Peter Schibli]

node.accessibility_caption: Photograph of a sculpture against a white background. The sculpture is a stuffed rabbit made with pantyhose and filled with tobacco leaves. It has beer-can tabs as eyes and a tuft of rabbit fur for a tail.

node.text:
What does giving someone a gift mean to you? The act of gifting can show the power of reciprocity and interdependence. 

Join a conversation exploring concepts of gifts and gifting next week on August 10 with artists and musicians #GabrielleLHirondelleHill, Muriel Miguel, Laura Ortman, Skeena Reece, George Stonefish, Tania Willard, and Tracy Williams moderated by Tailinh Agoyo and hosted by Lance Richmond and Frances Grumbly. Link in bio to learn more.
 
This event is presented in collaboration with the American Indian Community House (aichnyc), an organization founded in 1969 to improve and promote the well-being of the American Indian community, and accompanies the exhibition “Projects: Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill,” currently on view at MoMA through August 15.

[Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill. “Mint.” 2019. Pantyhose, beer-can tabs, tobacco, rabbit fur, and thread. 5 1/2 × 7 1/16 × 9 1/2″ (14 × 17.9 × 24.1 cm). Private collection, New York. Courtesy the artist and Unit 17, Vancouver, and Cooper Cole, Toronto © Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by MoMA The Museum of Modern Art on August 01, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 6 people, child, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Happy August! Grab some friends and hit the beach. 🏖️

“I wanted to be the photographer of happiness.”

Photographer Malick Sidibé was known as the “Eye of Bamako,” the capital city of Mali. Sidibé captured youth pop culture, nightlife, and fashion during a pivotal time as the country gained its independence.

[Malick Sidibé. “Friends.” 1976. Gelatin silver print, printed 2003. Gift of Jean Pigozzi]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by MoMA The Museum of Modern Art on July 31, 2021 tagging @jojackson87, and @xenllewellyn. May be an image of child and standing.

node.text:
“I do work that tends to be very beautiful, very physical.” 

In a time-intensive and laborious process, #HowardenaPindell’s paintings build up layers of paint, carefully placed fragments of hole-punched paper, shimmering glitter, and more.

Howardena Pindell worked as the first Black woman curator at MoMA in the decade before she made this painting. Following a 1979 life-threatening car accident and facing memory loss, Pindell began writing memories on collected postcards and incorporated photo transfers onto this piece.

📸 @xenllewellyn and @jojackson87

[Howardena Pindell. “Memory: Past.” 1980-81. Acrylic, dye, paper, thread, tempera, photographic transfer, glitter, and powder on canvas. Committee on Painting and Sculpture Funds and gift of The Friends of Education of The Museum of Modern Art]

node.text:
“It’s a contemplative painting for me, something that you can get lost in. This painting provides an opportunity to quiet my own mind.”

Cara Manes, Associate Curator in the Department of Painting and Sculpture, finds a haven from the chaos of the everyday in Vasudeo S. Gaitonde’s “Painting, 4.”
 
Explore our collection work by work as we release a new #UNIQLOArtSpeaks video each Friday, and experience "Painting, 4" in Gallery 404: Planes of Color.

node.text:
Did you know kids 16 and under always get in free? Celebrate summer at MoMA with your family! 

What’s on…
☀️ See iconic cars in our galleries and Sculpture Garden and consider how automobiles, for better and worse, have changed the world.
☀️ Get a once-in-a-generation look at Cézanne’s works on paper that takes you inside the artist’s mind.
☀️ Explore the Museum together with special audio, gallery labels, and activity guides for kids that let you draw, move, and imagine with art.
 
… and more! Link in bio to plan your day at MoMA.

📸 Gus Powell (@dirtywhitebucks)

node.text:
☄️ 40 years from today in 2061, Halley’s Comet is expected to be at “perihelion,” the point at which it is closest to the sun. The infamous comet was first photographed in the spring of 1910 after thousands of years of observations around the world.

One person had a particularly strong connection to Halley’s Comet…

Writer #MarkTwain was born during an appearance in 1835. In 1909 Twain said “I came in with Halley's Comet...it is coming again...and I expect to go out with it...The Almighty has said, no doubt: ‘Now here are these two unaccountable freaks; they came in together, they must go out together.’”

Twain did, in fact, come in and go out with Halley’s Comet when he passed away on April 10, 1910, one day after its perihelion.

See this photograph in Early Photographs and Film, a #MoMACollection gallery on view now.

[Yerkes Observatory. "Halley's Comet." 1910. Gelatin silver print. The New York Times Collection. © 2021 The New York Times. Digital Image © 2021 The Museum of Modern Art, New York]

node.text:
☂️ How does a parasol become a work of art? An #ArtTerm explained! “Assemblage” is a term used to describe three-dimensional works made from combinations of materials including found objects or non-traditional art materials.

In this piece, artist #NoahPurifoy adhered a parasol armature and handle, found wood, pasted papers, backgammon and poker chips, fishing pole, wire, bird cage parts, and other materials to a painted wood base. “Unknown” is a rare surviving example of the artist’s early assemblages. 

For this week's Hey Kids! Art Crew, look around for photographs, small toys, recycled and natural materials—you can use anything to make art! Use what you find to assemble your own multidimensional artwork, join us virtually on Thursday at 10am and 3pm to share what you’ve made with kids around the world. Recommended for ages six and up. Link in bio to learn more and join in!

[Noah Purifoy. "Unknown." 1967. Committee on Painting and Sculpture Funds. © Noah Purifoy Foundation]

node.text:
Into the corner, you should be ashamed of yourself! Have you seen this figure lurking at MoMA?
 
Artist #MartinKippenberger made full-scale replicas of himself as self-inflicted punishment after a vicious article was written about him titled "The Artist as Exemplary Alcoholic.” Kippenberger was known for his outrageous and provocative behavior, both in his art and his personal life. He created six versions of this sculpture, all uniquely clothed. While the other Martin figures are dressed more formally, this figure commissioned by MoMA wears Levi's jeans and a shirt with a globe on it.

Find Martin in our second floor gallery “After the Wall,” featuring works by European artists made in the wake of political and social revolutions of the late 1980s.

📸 @bradleybarnes_

[Martin Kippenberger. "Martin, Into the Corner, You Should Be Ashamed of Yourself." 1992. Cast aluminum, clothing, and iron plate. © 2021 Estate Martin Kippenberger, Galerie Gisela Capitain, Cologne] #MoMACollection

node.text:
“The geometry of abstraction made possible with a movie camera.” 

Multimedia artist #NeelonCrawford was a member of the 16-millimeter independent filmmaking scene in Ohio, San Francisco, and New York from the late 1960s through the early 1980s, producing 35 films experimenting with light, movement, and abstraction.

Now open! See nine of pieces meditating on climate crisis and sustainability, inspired by encounters with the classical elements of nature: earth, water, air, and fire in “Neelon Crawford, Filmmaker.” Link in bio to plan your visit.

[Excerpt. “Paths of Fire II.” 1976. USA. Directed by Neelon Crawford and Michael Mideke. Silent. 8 min.]
